Your daughter is assigned to an asylum because of attempting suicide. Somehow she has gone missing and it is up to you to find her.
At the beginning you can choose if you play as the father or the mother (no difference to game, just difference voices).

The Hat Man is fairly slow and not a real danger at all. You can easily walk through the rooms and collect the pages. To finish the game it takes something around 30 minutes.
The graphics are not great at all. The whole game is very repetitive, all rooms look the same.
The sound is okay but the voice acting is really awful.
The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is not scary at all and especially not worth 4,99 (former price was 14,99€).

reviewText:
Prepare to die screaming…or more likely laughing at the horrendously bad voice acting of ‘The Hat Man: The 20+ Pages’……wait….wrong game (and more on the voice acting later).

Alas, just as has happened with so many other indie horror games in recent years and with the advent of the Slender series, ‘The Hat Man:  Shadow Ward’ (the ‘for real’ name) falls victim to the same ‘collect quest’ gameplay  mechanic.  This means that you need to find a set number of pages from your daughter’s diary to complete the game.  Ultimately, that’s the basis of the game:  you either play as the father or mother in search of said daughter, who has gone missing from the seemingly empty asylum she was committed to which is now populated by shadow people/The Hat Man (BTW – the idea of shadow peeps is based loosely on fact and there are many documented cases, and even some decent movies, about people that have seen or had encounters with these so-called ‘Shadow People’).  Thankfully, you don’t just search for pages as you also need to find some other items to progress deeper into the asylum and defeat The Hat Man (who I guess is like the pimp of the shadow peeps) to get your daughter back.

One of the more unique attributes of this game (though it’s been done before) is that sound is utilized to pinpoint the location of pages/other items you need by means of whispery voices.  Also, the sound design of this game isn’t half bad for being a budget title, with some of the sound effects/ambient music being pretty creepy in my opinion.

Now as promised, I must go back to my earlier comment about the voice acting.  Granted, this game is super short and can be beat in less than half an hour, so you may think that voice acting wouldn’t be too important in such a game…..but it kinda, sorta totally is.  Essentially, it’s hilarious.  No, seriously, I’m not joking.  I mean, it’s so stupendously bad that it’s good (I don’t know how that works; it defies the human intellect to comprehend how that can be) but it’s true.  I figure most people will laugh at it, though some may actually want to cry at how bad it is.  And for all those 100% achievement unlock Steamers out there – prepare thine selves!!  There is actually an achievement for listening to your daughter reading the pages of her diary as you collect them.  Sure, this game can fairly easily be ‘100%’d’ and the aforementioned achievement is easy enough to unlock, but don’t go joy-puking your faces off just yet as I seriously believe that listening to all of the pages may very well land you in an asylum. I personally just barely managed to keep my sanity intact while unlocking this achievement, so don’t say I didn’t warn you.

This game can be fun for like 2 hrs tops, but I wouldn’t recommend it at full price, even if it is a budget title. With decent voice acting, who knows, perhaps this game could have been terrifying.  As it is, it will likely be overlooked by most gamers, but it is somewhat interesting and good for a laugh….or cry, so give it a shot.

I’ll admit I maybe spent longer studying The Hat Man: Shadow Ward’s death screen than it deserved. But it so nicely summed up the game for me that I couldn’t help but appreciate that I was being handed a focus point for my review without even having to look for it.

But let’s step back for a moment because it’s not just the death screen important here, but how you arrive at it. After scurrying through a twisting, self replicating maze of stock textures and out of place items, you’re inevitably caught the titular Hat Man in all his floating jack-o-lantern glory. And what’s this? He’s opening his mouth and- oh, I guess that wasn’t supposed to happen.

And just like that we’re transported to a perfectly flat, perfectly bland death screen featuring three buttons, each drawn with the same ugly font and taking up almost the entire screen. I realize it’s a screen that didn’t need to have much detail, but what’s here is such a pitiful excuse for a menu I couldn’t help but laugh at it.

I suppose I can give The Hat Man that much anyway; it made me laugh. First at the ridiculous voice acting that I want so much to believe was intentional. Then when turning around and laying eyes on what I think was supposed to be a terrifying demon but looked more like a blazing smile.

And finally at the death screen, which I saw many times and eventually decided was a good enough place to give this game a rest. After all The Hat Man is just doing his job haunting this asylum, and doing it damn well at that, so I’ll just leave him be and go do literally anything else to try to forget this ever happened.

So, I have to preface this game by pointing out that I was given this game for free by one of the only marketers that isn't an idiot in the industry, who handed keys for the game out free of charge to drum up press for the price drop and the free update.

Ignoring that, the game isn't actually bad, but it IS something you've probably played before; this game is a slightly more involved version of Slender.
If you weren't scared by Slender, or games like Slender, you won't be scared by this.
This is half of why my review may or may not be something you should listen to, because quite frankly this sort of thing is fairly distant from what I consider my affair.
You're chased by numerous ghosts and the HatMan, all of whom look like the bad guy from Ferngully. Also, you can find the credits to the game in a room, killing most of the atmosphere that's set by the idea that the game is based on a true story.
Aside from that, the environments are very enclosed, dark asylum settings, so it raises the question of whether you'd get this for cheap, Slender for cheaper, or Amnesia/Outlast for a bit more than this.

I do have to say if nothing else the game is actually reasonably priced when it's on sale for 20 cents, although five bucks may be a bit much.
I'm actually a bit torn, because I don't actually see this doing too well outside of 20 cents to a buck territory, because the entire presentation is fairly amateur and ends up being something I'd compare to free unity games, but damn that marketer was nice.
Can't say I can recommend this past a sale, because the actual content just isn't the sort of thing you'd usually see charged for.

reviewText:
A solid, low-budget first-person survival horror closely linked to  Slenderman: The Eight Pages , housing a fair amount of haunting images and thick atmosphere, evoking a handful of steady cold shivers and durable tension within its short run, mostly due to the eerie and restrained sound design.

Your daughter has gone missing from the asylum where she was being treated for attempting suicide. Once you enter the vacant facility, investigating her whereabouts, you begin looking for pages from your daughter's journal while being hunted by a dark presence wearing a hat.

The basic gameplay of finding a bunch of objects to unlock new areas for further exploration is quite easily comprehensible, yet it may be a fair disorienting challenge to obtain all 20+ pages since the randomly altering level design relocate the pages on each playthrough; though once you pinpoint the location of a page, whispery voices are in effect and narrowing it down become child's play.

The stiff level design is utterly mediocre at best and visually it is quite dull, but the ridiculously awkward voice-over is the shattering winner to listen to and hence should have been left out. Also, the poorly written dialogue comes out far more silly rather than intriguing, and finally - considering the source material that is based on real events - the outcome turns out quite immaterial.

At a discount however, coupled with appreciating solid scares, Game Mechanics' short piece of indie horror, regardless of being a Slender copy, earns a night's attention.

5,5 / 10

The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a must-have for gamers who love horror. I feel positively about most aspects of this game. First of all, the price. This game is very affordable at the price of £0.79, although I picked this up in a sale (£0.19!), and it is worth it! I feel this game is quite underappreciated for what it is. The plot of the game itself is interesting, but yet not very unique. A mental asylum is quite common to see in horror games, however, copying ideas can result in a better game overall (the way I feel about this game). In no way at all will I compare this game with other horror survival games such as Outlast or Alien: Isolation, but it must be said, this game is genuinely scary, what you'd look for in a horror game.

I feel the way this game's layout is set is great, for example, the beginning of this game has a few doors that I myself thought you'd be able to open, but cannot. This can result in disliking the game or liking it even more. For me, this tactic doesnt mean the map is too detailed, and I like that. Many times I've played games that have had too many places to go to, when in the end, all I had to do was go through the main door. Adding details like doors that canot be opened helps prevent wasting time, which is great, getting to the next point of the story without wasting time or lowering suspense.

Like I covered previously, the main obvious plot is not too unique, which isn't necessarily a bad thing at all! Having a man chase you through a mental asylum is, of course, going to be a common theme. (Please note, the actual story to this game is rather unique, and the fact it's based off a real life story makes it all the more scarier!).

The controls are easy to use, the game is not too basic nor complicated, and there are plenty of them (and they're rather familiar with other games). Graphics, textures are all fine, and the flow of gameplay compliments it well.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. I appreciate games like these that are affordable, fun to play, not complicated and that give you a few hours of enjoyment. I'd strongly recommend this to people who enjoy horror games.

reviewText:
The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is an indie horror game, seemingly heavily inspired by Slender and similar games. You play as the father(or mother, depending on which you pick) of a young girl who was sent to an Asylum. You receive a message telling you that your daughter is missing and you decide to go look for her in the Asylum. Upon entering her room and opening her diary the Asylum changes, the diary explodes and the first Shadow person appears. You are now compelled to gather all the pages of the dairy as the games gets progressively harder with each page. Overall, the game is pretty graphically outdated(it's an indie game with a limited budget), but they were able to get the spooks pretty well(the SFX were nice, too). The voice-acting is either purposely bad or just bad, so it kinda makes it hard to get scared when the voice-acting makes you wanna laugh. There are some bugs and the Shadow people are pretty slow and you get rid of them quite easily. One of the biggest issues was the fact that upon dying I was cast back to the beginning, hence I'd recommend a way of saving the game or just more checkpoints. If you wanna get some creepy atmosphere going I suggest buying the game on sale, there are better titles out there, but it's still pretty solid.

>I'd give it a 5/10
>Pros: Spooky atmosphere, achievements, randomly generated map, allegedly based on real stories.
>Cons: Bugs, inability to save/rare checkpoints, the enemies aren't that tough, voice-acting, short, graphics are outdated, the rooms look almost the same but it isn't that bad.

Disclosure: received free copy of the game.

Shortly described this is a Survival running horror game that has randomized elements as the map is different on every play trough. The hallways even change during the same session if one walks away far enough so it really is random.

Difficulty is quite tough and constant restarts actually reminds me of Receiver, a game that is not a horror game but has the same random map every time you play it and similar kind of (illusion) of choices - and both have quite tough difficulty that goes up slowly but surely.

I have no idea what people mean when they say in some reviews that this game is a walk in the park - they must mean earlier versions as after some 3 hours i have managed to beat the game only once using save points. So many things CAN and WILL go wrong even after you think you have the mechanics figured out.

For me the concept just works. I have a lot of horror games in my library but not a nifty little horror game title like this.  This game will not blow your mind and redefine the horror genre but in my books it doesn't need to. It is enough to preferably bring a new element and solid gameplay and you have a game worth it's price and this the game is able to do.

This is not a large game like Penumbra series/Amnesia nor is it a design marvel of a game squeezed into a tight space such as Anna.

Cons? Few but there are some. Rough edges here and there are annoying. Clicking on items is best done by clicking franticaly it seems. Beginning of the game is also weakest. For example if the game is so well into randomized hallways then i'd prefer to skip the early pleasantries after awhile. Also ghosts coming trough the floor at you can be a problem when changing floors so stairs require your full attention. I was also killed for the first time before i even got the flashlight. Tiny details like these which dont matter at all after some hours but add to the rough feeling in the first 30minutes. i'd also not see the face of the Hat Man at all during death. Like games better that leave it to players own imagination what happens when you get caught.  (sound can also  be sometimes more effective than visuals)

3 hours clocked at this time and will be expecting at least some hours more as i have not yet grown tired of the game. i'd say this is a good addition to the horror library.

reviewText:
This game starts with a somewhat interesting concept. You can choose between a mother and a father, which so far, the only difference that it makes is that your death scream is different. You're trapped in some kind of demonic ward, or should I say, a shadow ward? This ward is always changing, so you have to keep moving forwards all the time. You gotta collect pages, too, like in Slenderman games, but way more, and a few other items along the way like matches and levers. You pretty much run between corridors, and now and then, you'll hear some kind of whispering, telling you that there is an item in a side room. If you miss an item and leave the room, just keep running, there is no point in going back, it probably changed already.

The main enemy of this game, is the Hat Man, a being that from a distance kinda looks like a trenchcoat wearing guy with a hat, surrounded in a cloud of blackness and with a purple aura. Later on, he changes to something different, that's way faster and more persistent, adding a bit of fear to the mix.

That being said, the problem with these procedually generated games is that, sometimes, it's way too random. And in this game's case, sometimes you're going to be able to finish the game in less than 30 minutes, sometimes it's going to take way longer than that. It took me around 30 minutes for a room I needed to spawn. I even believed my game was bugged.

The game's atmosphere is kinda creepy at first, being chased by this creature that never stops. (Actually, he does, when you enter a certain kind of room, like stairs or the room with the pit)
It's got some weak jumpscares, too, like a ceiling light falling, or a wheelchair moving. The problem is, after running from the Hat Man for a while, and after seeing the same rooms and the same jumpscares over and over again over the period of....dozens of minutes....It kinda starts to get old rather fast. It's quite a short game, and it doesn't offer much. It's really, really cheap, too. So, all in all, it feels stale, and it gets old rather fast, but I did find it fun for a short while. Maybe playing lots of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games myself kinda made me more tolerant to this kind of stuff, but, If it's on sale, why not? You could try it for yourself.

reviewText:
The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is an indie horror adventure game. You play as the father or the mother of a girl who has gone missing in an insane asylum. You arrive in the asylum to go looking for her, but there is nobody in the asylum except for a ghostlike creature called the Hat Man. You spend the game running away from the Hat Man and meanwhile collecting two kinds of items:
- diary pages written by your daughter, explaining a bit what's going on and what you need to do next
- items that help you advance e.g. at the very start there is a barricaded door => you pick up a nearby axe and use it to remove the obstacle

The asylum's hallways and rooms are continuously generated at random. So I didn't really like the fact that you couldn't rely on your memory and orientation skills to find your way in the asylum. You just need to keep running until you come across the item you need to advance to the next part of the asylum.

What I did like about 'The Hat Man: Shadow Ward' is that you get a short thrilling experience for nearly no money at all. When I finished the game, I was surprised to see I got the achievement for finishing the game in under half an hour. It seemed longer what with the running around through the endless hallways and what with reloading when caught by the Hat Man. But the game shouldn't have been any longer than it is, because it's too 'basic' to entertain for hours. Now, at the price of this game (and especially when on sale) I think it's certainly worth playing if you're into the horror-atmosphere type games and are willing to settle for a quick, cheap fix.

You are either the father or mother (you get to choose) of a daughter who has been put into a mental ward for her own safety. The thing is something has happened there, and even though you were told to stay away you have decided to check up on your daughter. That's where things start getting even stranger. You leave the elevator and can't seem to find anyone around. You locate your daughter's room and find a journal with a strange looking face on it. Upon touching it you are transported into the Shadow Ward.

The journal's page scatter in a strange wind that pulls through the mental ward when you touch the journal. You will have to collect the pages if you are ever going to find out what has happened to your daughter, and perhaps find a way out of this situation for yourself. You see once you enter the Shadow Ward you will find that you are no longer alone.

In The Hat Man: Shadow Ward, you will find that there is a shadow being that goes by the name of the Hat Man. The Hat Man seems to be stalking the halls, and if he catches you you will be paralyze, your soul stolen, and if you wish to try your luck again, you will have to start from scratch.

On the outside this looks like a very scary game where there's going to be tons of jump out of your seat scares, and to be honest when the Hat Man catches you, most of the time it will make you jump out of your skin. The only problem is some of the mechanics. When I talk about mechanics I'm talking about several things in the game.

The first mechanic is the randomization of the game layout. I'm all for changing things up through each playthrough, but that being the case I feel like this game would have GREATLY benefited from a checkpoint system. The way I would have done it is that you have to collect the pages in groups of five. I do understand that this would probably screw up the random locations of the pages, but I think there is a level of frustration that starts to creep in, especially since the Hat Man's location could literally be in the wall in the room you start your adventure into the Shadow Ward.

The second mechanic is the inventory system, maybe it's my computer, but it took an act of God to change items that were currently equipped. Now thankfully you're going to be spending the majority of the time with the flashlight in hand, but it would have been nice if the game would have allowed a smoother transition between items.

The third mechanic surrounds the journal pages. Part of what makes this game creepy is what is written in the journal pages, and currently the only way to actually find out what are in the pages you picked up is to go into the journal. Why not just have the audio start to play upon picking up the page so that the player isn't taken out of the game to find out what is on the pages? Oh and if you have to go into the journal to find out what is written on them, the audio should probably match up to ALL entries. There's at least one case that I can think of off the top of my head where the page had something other than what was being said to me.

The thing is this game has that spookiness to it that will keep people on edge, but with just enough randomness to cause people to get frustrated. I know its a race against time as you try to stay 2 steps in front of the Hat Man as you try to recover all the journal pages, but when his location seems to be randomized, and the first playthrough I met my demise without ever really getting into the game, it kind of kills the want to play again.

I'm going to be totally honest, I have yet to fully complete the game, but it isn't from a lack of trying. The only way that I've been able to get anywhere in this game is from constantly sprinting through the entire game, and listening for the whispers, that's when you know you are close to another journal page. I appreciate that there are items hidden in the game that cause you to have to really search the area, but without a map to refer to and the fact that you have to stay constantly on the run, there's a really good chance that a player could be doing a large loop over and over again not knowing what to do, scared that if they slow down and start to really investigate the Hat Man will appear, and you'll have to start all over again.

So here's the deal, this game has its moments, and I think it is possible, if all the stars align that this could be the experience that I think the developers are hoping the player gets, but with all the random variables, and the fact that the Hat Man can strike right off the bat, this game is too much of a game of chance to really enjoy. This game gets a 6.2 out of 10.

The Hat Man: Shadow Ward... Basically a worse Slender game with more pages, and a slight advantage when collecting them.
~~~
Story:
You can play as the mother or father of a girl, Virginia Berry, who was put in an insane asylum for attempting suicide. Virginia has gone missing, and you go a look for her. You pick up her journal, and it 'corrupts' you, and you must collect all 22 pages, and a few other items to save your daughter before the 'Shadow People' get you and capture your soul. As you collect the pages, it tells you a story of her reading the book about the HatMan after a woman told her to. She wasn't sure why, but she did.
~~~
A little Canton Insane Asylum background:
Canton's Asylum is located in West Virginia in the United States. Congress has passes a bill creating the only 'Institution of Insane Indians' in the US. (So, I'm guess this family was Indian. [That's beside the point.]) It was opened in January 1903, this asylum was also sometimes called Hiawatha Insane Asylum. Many inmates put here were not mentally ill. The asylum closed in 1934. Atleast 121 died, and more than 350 patients were detained here.
Flaws:
-TV's were not invented until the 1927's. So I don't think that the TV's with static were a good placement for this time period.
-I think if the developers did a little research on the place and time era, they could have made a better plot, giving an more intreaging story, and a better experience.
~~~
Sound:
The sounds were hilarious for this game. The voice overs for the daughter, mother, and father, and the Hat Man. The Hat Man, when he takes you is the best noise in this game. (I'm kidding, it's also really bad.)
To be honest, I actually like the music from the music players. They are not too bad.
The pages make a whispering noise that is very obnoxious, and annoying. Maybe not to others, but to me, I did not like the noises for them.
-If more time was put into the sound, it could have helped enchance the game play, and actually make this is a scary game.
~~~
Challenge:
This game really isn't challenging... wait. Why can't I pick up my axe again after I used it? Okay...
~~~
I wouldn't recommend this game. The play time is short, and not very interesting to me. I would not replay it after I beat it, which I won't beat.

reviewText:
The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a horror game that sends you off in a hospital hell to collect journal pages and overcome obstacles in an attempt to bring your daughter home. Using a simple search-and-find-the-pages mechanic used in other very famous horror games, The Hat Man also adds the twist of having a changing maze inside the asylum so that one hallway isn't always the one you just came from. You're fleeing The Hat Man, a paranormal anomaly called a shadow person, who feeds upon the sick and weak. Did I mention he can teleport? He does that.

A lot.

God I'm gonna steal that stupid hat and throw it down the hall and see if that'll distract him. I digress.

The game isn't difficult. Notes are shrouded in whispers so as you find yourself outside a room containing one, the whispers within your head becoming maddening (they might even drive you...insane? RIMSHOT.) Your foe moves slowly enough that you can out run him or you can hide if you find a perfect method of how to do it. Rooms are spacious that if you plan things, you can loop around to bypass the hovering spectre. That is, if you're quick about it. I didn't have so much luck with this. I ended up rushing into walls and getting caught just by that last second and ended up starting over. Sigh.

As this is a horror game, you're probably asking just how scary is it. Shadow people, as we know them, tend to be these looming types that are said to stand there and make you feel uncomfortable. The Hat Man is designed well enough that he gives you a you a nice shock when he teleports right into your face in a very literal way. One second you've left him five hallways away and POOF, there he is! You can also see him coming from a good distance off so you're feeling pretty free to give him the finger. He's not gruesome, but just unsettling enough that he reinforces the stories of shadow people being vague, smoky, and shadowy outlines of people who are unable to take proper forms. He's a bit menacing so that was good enough for me. Good enough for me to swear every time he tried to tickle me with those ugly hands.

As for the feel of the game, I mentioned it's a good hospital hell. You've got rotting bodies, the sound of people crisping against defibs (I jumped a foot), the traditional falling ceiling tiles, loud noises to freak you out as you turn corners, and the much appreciated radio playing assorted music. I loved the pieces that made me feel like it was a Twilight Zone episode. The radio is a nice touch. It's something a lot of games do, but not many use them so nicely as this, I believe.

You can play as the father or mother. This has no bearing on the story. Your child's sarcasm and dull humor as noted in the diary OBVIOUSLY comes from your commentary. You are a parent on a mission and somehow you even make some off-color comments at the start of this adventure. (Father calls the asylum a funhouse. Mother says homemaker turned homewrecker.) Upon reading the journal, even your daughter has found time to make off-color comments about her own situation. The apple has not fallen far from the tree. This amused me greatly. I didn't find it out of character at all. It seems like a perfect defense mechanism in a horrible time like that. (Referring to her attempts as a been there

reviewText:
Page collector 2014.

This is not a terrible game.  It just is not a great game.  It is an average game that I found boring.

The game is made in Unity.  You can play as either the father or the mother searching for their lost daughter in the insane asylum.  There are voice overs, and the acting is competent.   It isn't terrible, but it isn't outstanding.  Like everything in this game.

As mentioned, the game is in Unity.  The engine is smooth.  The graphics are not outstanding, but it animates well.  Moving your character is intuitive, although I found the movement a little awkward at times.  When there is something you can interact with a little hand will appear, and that is when you click.

The entire game, however, is just a search for pages of your daughters diary.  There are a few mild scares, and the setting in general tries to be unsettling.  Walking around a generic assylum that was dark looking for paper.... well, it just got boring.

If the game is on sale and you have some time to kill for a very average horror experience, pick it up.  Otherwise there are better ways to spend your gaming time.

5/10

reviewText:
Game: The Hat Man: Shadow Ward
Genre: Survival horror
Developer: Game Mechanics
Publisher: Game Mechanics
Copy supplied by developer

The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a first-person survival horror game set in an asylum developed and published by Game Mechanics.

STORY
You play as either the father or mother of Virginia Berry, who disappeared from the asylum where she was being treated for attempting suicide. As you go and investigate her disappearance, you find no one in the asylum and you start looking for pages from your daughter's journal while being chased by a shadowy figure.
Unlike most horror games of this nature, reading the notes and discovering what your daughter was living through is more interesting than simply looking at doodles and drawings of the monster. Unfortunately, the plot really goes nowhere and is disposable at best for the game.

GRAPHICS
As far as Unity games go, this doesn't stand out from the crowd. The environments are polished and I didn't encountered many bugs, but the rooms all look the same and it becomes really hard to navigate the environment. The design of the titular villain and the shadow people isn't really scary, and once you see them the built-up scariness that never existed disappears.

GAMEPLAY
Similarly to Slenderman: The Eight Pages, you must move through the environment looking for pages while avoiding being caught by the Hat Man. You will also need to find some objects to open new areas and further explore the asylum. The pages are really easy to find since they make a noise when you are near them, and the shadow people can be defeated" by hitting'em with your flashlight "Alan Wake style" but much worse as it doesn't work half the time.

reviewText:
Well the dev added me and gave me this for free so I feel like I should be nice and give him a good review on this but I also want to be honest because this is one of the worst games I have played in a long time. Before I say anything else I can definitely say that I fully appreciate the time and talent of the people who make games, good or bad, because it isn't easy. To the game's credit it had no technical issues and controlled and performed very smoothly. There is no in-game vsync so I had to force it through Nvidia control panel, but no biggie. Unless I missed it, there is also no mouse sensitivity option so I had to lower it in my razer synapse but also no big deal. Although I am not a fan of adventure games I felt like I owed it to this guy to try his game and give it my honest opinion. The game lacks heavily in detail (basically none) and overall production value. The graphics are a major turn off. The game was very, very bland and very boring. The graphics look like pre Half-Life 1 and the environment is almost empty, only adorned with a few tables and a radio, a few beds in some rooms, sinks and toilets, a few things on the walls, and nothing else. It is very plain and mostly empty. I think the game repeats on itself, meaning there was no end as I moved in a direction through doors and hallways and the environment kept repeating. A piece of ceiling fell down with a scary music que eventually so I guess if you wander enough more things happen. Really though I'm not sure. Three times I encountered a black ghost (Bill Cosby from Ghost Dad I think) with a BOO! cartoon halloween style face and the game just popped up the dead menu, showing restart and quit. Nothing happened, just dead and menu screen. I do not know how the black figure is triggered, or why, or how to avoid him if I see him, or what the point of the game is or what exactly I am supposed to be doing, and overall don't care to see the answer to any of those inquiries. Note: I read that you just go around and collect journal pages and avoid the black figure and the game can be beat in like 30 minutes. That could have saved me a lot of words in my review.

Out of 50+ installed games, this game just can't hold an audience with me anymore. 20 minutes was more than enough time spent on this. Although I dislike adventure games, I have played a few out there that are similarly priced (when on sale which is often if you know where to look) that are far superior in every aspect. Namely Outlast. Where this game would be a 3/10 Outlast would be a 8/10, easily trumping this game in every possible aspect.

This game is so depressingly void of any real substance in terms of graphics/visual content and gameplay that it is what truly makes it scary. Imagine the inside of a cardboard box with a few miniature doll house chairs and tables and beds set up in it and that is what this game looks like.

Thanks for the game. Sorry that it completely blows!

The sad part is... I've played scarier games for free. I'm pretty sure this *isn't* the scariest game of 2014.

This *was* a fifteen dollar game that made Daylight look good. It's dropped to five and I suppose that's more reasonable than Daylight.

The game itself is an obvious Slender clone, where you're running around grabbing pages while avoiding the monster. Unlike slender, however, the monster doesn't ever teleport. reviewText:
Thank you to the senpai studios for the free review copy.

We live in an awesome time where small teams (and in many cases, one person) can create indie games and share them with the world. I love indie games. The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is obviously a labor of love for senpai studios, and I highly encourage them to keep doing what they are doing. There is alot of promise in this work, but unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game. What I can offer is some constructive critiscm.

1. While there are minute differences, it shares all too much with the Slenderman series. I fault that series for the same things found here - the mechanic it is built on is too simple, and the gimmick wears off quickly. That game concept works best as phone or tablet games. To explain further - finding book pages while avoiding a ghost is boring. Maybe if you added RPG-like elements and extended gameplay? Criticism should always be supported with possible options for a fix, IMO.

2. Graphics are bland, at best. If you cannot make it hyper-realistic, I would try to go for a retro look. What you have here is something that falls in the middle, and ultimately just looks like every other basic FPS game. I would bet this was made in some GML or game making program (I don't believe senpai studios actually built those wheelchairs sprite by sprite). Once again, I am just trying to seed ideas.

3. Maybe get rid of the voice acting, and just add captions.

4. Make the Hat Man scarier, and much faster. Maybe make his 'darkness' totally creep and cover your entire view. As-is, he feels like a polygon on a rail.

5. I would do something risky - everything that is currently in this game has been done before. In many cases, it has been done better before. Maybe add split-screen co-op where the second player plays as the Hat Man. Might make for a good couch co-op romp. Who knows?

Thank you for reading the above ideas, and thank you again to senpai studios for the free copy. I seriously commend you for seeing the complete developemental process to finish. Not many can actually do that. Keep up the hard work. For my Steam friends - pass on this one.

Peace,

-Ryan

Early Access Review

This game is utterly terrifying. The first time I played this I thought it would be just one of those boring repetitive jump scare games, but I was wrong. The build up towards your death is the most terrifying; not the death itself, as the loud ghostly noises, the creepy whispering when you get close to the journals,  the sounds of the hat man crawling above you; rattling the ceiling panels or a wheel chair ghostly pushed makes you think that he's right around the corner, behind you or in a door way which keeps you on edge throughout.

The thing that I would like to be improved on is when the hat man finally pops up, as for me it wasn't that scary since he appeared at the end of the corridor where I could easily see him and didn't even chase me. So to improve on this you should make him appear from behind you,  grab you through a missing celling panel or try and grab you though a toilet, as there are so many of them. Also it would be awesome if you added flares to light up rooms that you don't want to go in and make the torch flicker or go out to add even more scares.

Just to say this is an early access game; it won't be a fully perfect game, so don't buy this if you’re looking for a finished game and just wait until it comes out. But honestly this game is so worth getting if you love indie horror games and is just amazing, to say that it’s an early access game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a new Horror game that presents a great atmosphere and makes the hairs on the back of your neck stand up, The Hat Man: Shadow Ward just might be for you. Taking inspiration from Amnesia: The Dark Descent's ambiance, puzzle/collection-based objectives from a variety of games, and cues from psudo-folklore-derived games like Slenderman, The Hat Man has a lot of familiar and tried-and-true aesthetics while presenting new gameplay elements that are quickly becoming extremely popular for video games, especially in the Horror genre--namely, that it's very replayable. The map generates randomly, and if you stray too far from any one spot, it will have changed completely when you try to return to it.

If there's one thing that the Horror genre in general relies on, it's atmosphere. As a music composer/writer, I can say with great confidence that what I say next cannot be easily refuted, which is thus: A game that desires to scare, unsettle, unnerve, and frighten, must take great care in creating an experience that tips the audience off-balance, makes them lose their footing, and just when they think they're back on their feet, you pull the rug out from under them. If a Horror game cannot disturb and create suspense, it is operating completely wrong.

Now, of course, your mileage may vary, and various games may not neccessarily scare you. But, for me, anyway, The Hat Man does a great job at creating suspense and keeping me on my toes; like watching the fishing reel scene from Jaws, you'd be utterly amazed at what happens when you just focus on the ambience and the sound effects. In truth, they can sometimes be quite scarier than what's actually trying to scare you. In this regard, I think the developers of this game chose a great collection to work with. This game relies on building suspense and atmosphere rather than relying on conventional jump scares like most other Horror games. In fact, there's only maybe a handful of them in this game, if you can even call some of them so. A refreshing and welcome change of pace, in my opinion.

All-in-all, a fun game. I can't wait to see what is added and done in the final release. If it's great already, I can scarcely imagine what will happen in the future. To the developers, I say great job, and keep at it.

Early Access Review

Absolutely terrifying!

The atmosphere is so thick with terror and the desire to just not progress further. It's actually to the point where I need to conjure up bravey to press on in certain circumstances.

There are a couple of things that I absolutele WISH you guys in the developement team could consider:

(these are all things that I expected to happen because of my paranoid nature in-game)

1: Sound lures the Hat Man to you vicinity (Also encourages stealth and focus in a very trying atmosphere)

2: The ability to possibly see him on top of the fallen ceiling-spaces (to encourage a panic causing possibly more trouble)

3: Footsteps, which either i couldn't hear in all the terror, or they just haven't been added yet. (maybe a good echo depending on the acoustics of the room too!)

4: A reflection in a mirror that perhaps isn't broken (which could show the Hat Man behind you on occasion)

5: Perhaps a darker atmosphere to emphasize how important the flashlight or matches are to the player.

6: See the Hat Man PASS a corridor ahead. Where he completely crosses the threashhold of an intersection in front of you. (I have never seen him do that, he's only ever crossed halfway and turned to run at me)

7: Seeing the Hat Man peek out from corners (just a little touch to mess with the player)

8: Maybe even getting captured by the Hat Man only to wake up in a completely unfamiliar area without the flashlight?

9: upon opening a door, he would be on the other side, to attack you; could directly correlate to the above suggestion to where opening doors could lead to your capture and loss of the flashlight (this in my opinion would make players who experience this more likely to not want to open a door in the future, leading to more gameplay)


These are all just things that have crossed my mind during my TINY time of gameplay and while watching countless let's plays. Also in my opinion, it's the little things that most don't notice that are the most terrifying.
Because when someone DOES notice something small- that's not actually a trick of the eye, then they WILL continue to see other small things that might not all be genuinely coded.

All in all, I give the game 9.5/10 terror-induced-craps

I hope to see more of the small things in this BIG game!

-TJ Stratford

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far I'm loving this game. It does remind me a bit of Slender, but without the annoying mechanic that fuzzes over the camera .

Graphics: 7/10: It has a very creepy and proper feel to it, but the graphics can get a bit old after a while. Granted it's in beta, so hopefully during official release it will have been touched up. The monster has a rather nice graphics effect when it gets closer and can be seen, granted the ACTUAL Hat Man, is rather hard to make out within the fog till he's right up on you.

Sound/Music: 6/10 The sounds and audio are great at first, but after a while they stop being scary, especially when you're having trouble finding pages and are feeling frustrated. The heartbeat mechanic of Hat Man getting closer, is a rather awesome way to tell how close he is and act accordingly, but during the last several pages, when he is popping up all the time (in some of my videos like ever 30 seconds or less), it can get extremely annoying as it becomes all you hear. Still it's in beta, hopefully that'll be polished a bit to where he doesn't pop up so often when you're being super cautious or it isn't as deafening. This is a game you have to play with the sound though, otherwise finding pages will be EXTREMELY hard.

Gameplay: 7?/10: I put the ? because I may changed it and move it up, at the present point, I still haven't beaten the game (13 out of ?? pages), though I've finally started to get the hang of it. Hat man is a nice enemy as you can sneak by him and even juke around him (this requires some skill), the stealth works very nicely in the game and leads to some funny survival moments. As you collect more, it seems that real traps start to appear (or there is just a giant pitfall to your death at one point). My only issue with the gameplay is that it's not entirely clear what somethings are for, namely the Matches...I've found Matches, I think they unlock more pages (as I get stuck on 7 pages, find a box and boom I start finding more), maybe a tiny bit of clarity on that...granted could be a journal page I haven't gotten to read yet.

Overall: 7/10 likely to improve up with future edit. It's a good game, if you like this type of game. It could be a little more clear on some issues and have some audio configuration options (there is no way to effect the sound which means if you record, you'll be lower the games sound level during editing). I'd say buy it, especially before it gets closer to finished and increases in price.

Early Access Review

The hat man is a horror game, which upon first inspection seems rather unfrefined.

However, the game itself provides the user with a disturbed atmosphere, with both the sound and visual design being almost flawless.

Although the user is not currently provided with a clear understanding of objective (we thought it ended after collecting 5 notes) the game looks like it has a lot of potential should the developers continue to work on this issue.

THe hat man himself, however, is a dissapointing, anti-climactic and abrupt end to the game. The model quality lacks and you end up being more afraid of wheelchairs and lights than the hat man himself.

PLEASE. PLEASE. Work on the Hat Man, the user should be afraid of him, they should not be able to wander the map for almost an hour without seeing him. Perhaps using mechanics similar to 'One Late Night' would suit the gameplay.

I hope you take this into consideration, I look forward to seeing how the game develops.

TL;DR Great atmosphere but the Hat Man isn't all he is hyped up to be. It's not just about the review anymore.

What's good about The Hat Man? Well, it looks nice. It runs well. It's short, and has both achievements and trading cards.

You wander around the halls of an asylum collecting pages, and eventually a tall shadowy figure named Slenderman The Hat Man comes after you, slowly, so very slowly. reviewText: An intensely fun little horror game that'll provide amusement for some time - Definitely worth trying if you like underrated horrors. It's an interesting plot and I like that you can choose your character (kinda) but it would be nice if there was more variety? Once the game is done, that's it. It's done. Maybe if there were more characters with different reasons for going, it'd be fun for longer. But it also definitely needs a small tutorial or some on-screen hints as some things aren't always immediately clear - Like, how to kill the shadow people or how to escape The Hat Man when he appears. Still, a great game to play, I even competed with a friend to see who could get further...

This game is a test whether you have or do not have in-game luck. The Hatman can spawn whenever and wherever he wants, so you cannot be safe anywhere and game can end at any time.

When I played for the first time, I was legitimately scared as atmosphere and sound effects did their job perfectly. However, if you want to get all the achievements prepare to be extremely annoyed, bored and not scared as playing this game for hours will make you horror-proof :^)

P.S. For those who cannot complete “A good book” achievement. I completed it after replaying the game for 4 times. The successful attempt was by playing as the mother and listening to the pages right after picking them up.
